snippet: After Jodi Arias was convicted of the murder of her former boyfriend, the jurors must now turn to the difficult question of whether her crime deserves the death penalty.
abstract: Jurors in murder trial of Jodi Arias, after convicting her of murdering former boyfriend Travis Alexander, must now turn to difficult question of whether her crime deserves death penalty; jurors on many previous capital cases say that they were unprepared for emotional impact of sentencing phase, and that deciding to impose death penalty is painfully difficult.

byline.contributor: Susan C. Beachy and Jack Begg contributed research.

lead_paragraph: After Jodi Arias was convicted of the murder of her former boyfriend, the jurors must now turn to the difficult question of whether her crime deserves the death penalty.

headline.seo: After Conviction of Jodi Arias, Deciding on the Death Penalty
headline.main: After Verdict, Sentencing Is a New Trial for Jurors
headline.print_headline: After Verdict, Sentencing Is a New Trial For Jurors
